Comments_List: themes were presented that i previously had never taken into consideration
Learned more about evaluating the readings, as we had to write a critical response about all the readings, learned more about the different sides on controversial issues
Jonathan and Roger facilitated conversation better than any professors ive ever had

Strengths: very interesting topic, insightful on current issues of America and Islam, professors were very knowledgeable

Weaknesses: because we dont know enough about the topics, the professors would lecture for most of the seminar, with little inputs especially for the first few weeks

I would recommend if you are into history and politics, and really want to look at the flaws of American nationalism and identity and its war with Islam, which is very relevant today 
However its a lot of work, the readings are interesting but take up a lot of time, as well as the critical response essays due every week, which takes up A LOT of time because a critical response (a 400/500 word essay due every week) requires you to have actually read the readings thoroughly, and the readings could be a whole book and more a week 
Less of a discussion during seminars, sometimes discussion was taken over by some students who had sufficient background in politics, if you dont have much background its hard to contribute

I would definitely recommend this course to another student -- the combination of a historical look at race and religion in the U.S. and current events in the media has been an interesting and unique take on social science at Yale. The syllabus was an excellent blend of theory and modern events, and class discussions were fascinating.
